Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Bio-Advantaged Monomers for the Production of Function-Tailorable Polyamides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project scales the production of renewable monomers that give access to performance nylon polyamides with tailorable functional properties for applications in the automotive, food & beverage packaging, textiles, and other industries. The revolutionary technology will be a disruptive force to the $40 billion nylon polyamide industry by addressing nylon?s weaknesses such as undesired moisture adsorption, which results in loss of dimensional stability and tensile strength. These shortcomings lead industries to make compromises in selecting their materials; for instance, longer chain polyamides are used for moisture resistance but at the expense of desired viscoelastic properties. The proposed bio-advantaged monomers will 1) help ease reliance on petroleum-based chemicals resulting in greener production processes and a cleaner environment, 2) present new opportunities for innovation and use of performance plastics due to the platform that bio-advantaged monomers offer. This is expected to generate new jobs at multiple points in the value chain. Demand for agricultural goods by fermentation facilities will increase. Sumatra Biorenewables and its partners will create jobs to meet demand for monomer production and purification. Finally, polymer producers and the manufacturing industry will produce superior products, increasing the competitiveness of the U.S. chemical industry.

The intellectual merit of this project is to combine fermentation and chemical conversion for the production of bio-advantaged monomers and their corresponding performance-enhanced polyamides. The inexpensive, robust, and efficient monomer production process in conjunction with the customizable nature of bio-advantaged monomers to yield nylon derivatives that are hydrophobic, flame retardant, anti-static, or otherwise tailorable, afford opportunities to meet a number of needs in the manufacturing sector. The innovation?s success hinges on a monomer production process that utilizes an inexpensive electrochemical conversion that operates near 100% efficiency and that only uses water as a reactant and electricity as an energy source. In addition, the monomer production process is insensitive to the feedstock source and the impurities present in fermentation broths. Therefore, separation and purification is only required after monomer production, resulting in huge cost savings. Laboratory-tested samples of hydrophobic nylon perform equally well as dry nylon, but without the disadvantage of moisture sensitivity. This project will enable Sumatra Biorenewables to transition to a continuous flow, kilogram-scale, production process and supply potential customers with samples for performance testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sumatra Biorenewables LLC is a technology provider that made possible the cost-effective production of trans-3-hexenedioic acid (3HDA) (which until date had never been achieved by available technology) from the electrochemical hydrogenation of biologically produced muconic acid (MA). This novel biobased monomer can be used as a comonomer in the synthesis of high-performance engineering plastics, i.e. Nylon-6,6 (normally synthetized through the polycondensation reaction of adipic acid and hexamethyldiamine), for applications in the automotive, packaging, and residential and industrial goods industries. The introduction of 3HDA in nylons through copolymerization provides an ethylenic bond that enables the production of polyamides with tailored functional properties without altering the intrinsic nature of the polymeric material. This innovation is significant as it allows flexibility to meet customer demands, therefore expanding the range of applications that these already popular polyamides have, by tuning, for example, their physical, mechanical, hydrophilic-hydrophobic, and/or their anti-static properties, see Figure 1.

Sumatra's Phase I research was focused on scaling the 3HDA production to a kilogram-scale, which was then supplied to potential customers for testing. This step helped Sumatra generate the data needed to design the 3HDA electrochemical conversion process in ASPEN Plus and setting the foundation for the next stage in Sumatra's commercialization plan: the production of more than 10 kilograms per week of 3HDA.

During the customer discovery of the Phase-I grant, we recognized that a major pain point in the polyamide industry is the fact that Nylon-6,6 has the tendency to readily absorb water, up to 5% by weight, resulting in the loss of desired mechanical properties. As an example, Nylon-6,6 absorption of 2 wt% of moisture results in a drop in Young's modulus (stiffness) by about 40%. Additionally, this problem causes industry to spend in average an extra 15-20 hours drying Nylon-6,6 before it can be used. These findings motivated Sumatra to further develop 3HDA into a hydrophobic functionalized 3HDA, as our minimum viable product (MVP), by chemically grafting an aliphatic chain to the ethylenic bond in 3HDA.

At the end this Phase I project, Sumatra  was able to successfully demonstrated the feasibility of the technology for the production of 3HDA and was able to produce and send approximately 1 kilogram of the MVP to one of the world largest producer of Nylon-6,6. This action resulted in a 16-month interaction between the two companies and currently there is ongoing negotiations to establish a joint development agreement to further develop 3HDA's hydrophobic applications.


Last Modified: 03/06/2020
Modified by: Nacu B Hernandez

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Sumatra Biorenewables LLC is a technology provider that made possible the cost-effective production of trans-3-hexenedioic acid (3HDA) (which until date had never been achieved by available technology) from the electrochemical hydrogenation of biologically produced muconic acid (MA). This novel biobased monomer can be used as a comonomer in the synthesis of high-performance engineering plastics, i.e. Nylon-6,6 (normally synthetized through the polycondensation reaction of adipic acid and hexamethyldiamine), for applications in the automotive, packaging, and residential and industrial goods industries. The introduction of 3HDA in nylons through copolymerization provides an ethylenic bond that enables the production of polyamides with tailored functional properties without altering the intrinsic nature of the polymeric material. This innovation is significant as it allows flexibility to meet customer demands, therefore expanding the range of applications that these already popular polyamides have, by tuning, for example, their physical, mechanical, hydrophilic-hydrophobic, and/or their anti-static properties, see Figure 1. Sumatra's Phase I research was focused on scaling the 3HDA production to a kilogram-scale, which was then supplied to potential customers for testing. This step helped Sumatra generate the data needed to design the 3HDA electrochemical conversion process in ASPEN Plus and setting the foundation for the next stage in Sumatra's commercialization plan: the production of more than 10 kilograms per week of 3HDA. During the customer discovery of the Phase-I grant, we recognized that a major pain point in the polyamide industry is the fact that Nylon-6,6 has the tendency to readily absorb water, up to 5% by weight, resulting in the loss of desired mechanical properties. As an example, Nylon-6,6 absorption of 2 wt% of moisture results in a drop in Young's modulus (stiffness) by about 40%. At the end this Phase I project, Sumatra was able to successfully demonstrated the feasibility of the technology for the production of 3HDA and was able to produce and send approximately 1 kilogram of the MVP to one of the world largest producer of Nylon-6,6. This action resulted in a 16-month interaction between the two companies and currently there is ongoing negotiations to establish a joint development agreement to further develop 3HDA's hydrophobic applications.
